verdict.summary: The SSL/TLS certificate presented by the server has passed its expiration date. The certificate must be renewed and replaced on the server, or the client must be configured to trust a new certificate.

dead_ends.action: Set system clock back to before certificate expiry
dead_ends.why_fails: This is a temporary hack that creates far worse problems: log timestamps become invalid, cron jobs misfire, Kerberos auth breaks, and the certificate will still appear expired to remote clients performing their own time validation.

dead_ends.action: Disable SSL certificate verification globally in the client application
dead_ends.why_fails: While this suppresses the error, it completely defeats the purpose of TLS by allowing man-in-the-middle attacks. It also masks other certificate issues and creates a security vulnerability that is easy to forget to revert.

dead_ends.action: Downgrade OpenSSL to an older version that is more lenient with expired certs
dead_ends.why_fails: Older OpenSSL versions have known security vulnerabilities (e.g., Heartbleed). The expired certificate is still expired regardless of client version, and modern servers may reject connections from outdated TLS implementations.

workarounds.action: Renew the SSL certificate using the original CA or a new provider
workarounds.how:
1. Generate a new CSR: openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr
2. Submit CSR to your CA (Let's Encrypt, DigiCert, etc.) for renewal
3. Install the new certificate on the server
4. Restart the web server / application
5. Verify with: openssl s_client -connect host:443 | openssl x509 -noout -dates

workarounds.action: Set up automatic certificate renewal with Let's Encrypt and certbot
workarounds.how:
1. Install certbot: apt install certbot
2. Obtain cert: certbot certonly --webroot -w /var/www/html -d yourdomain.com
3. Enable auto-renewal: systemctl enable certbot.timer
4. Test renewal: certbot renew --dry-run
5. Add post-renewal hook to restart your server in /etc/letsencrypt/renewal-hooks/deploy/

workarounds.action: For internal services, regenerate a self-signed certificate with a longer validity period
workarounds.how:
1. Generate new self-signed cert: openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -days 365 -nodes
2. Deploy the new cert to the server
3. Distribute the new cert to all clients that need to trust it
4. Restart the service

leads_to.condition: when certificate is renewed but intermediate CA chain is not updated
when server is restarted during certificate replacement

preceded_by.condition: when ignoring verify failures leads to eventual expiry discovery
when DNS issues masked the expiry until DNS was fixed

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Expired certificates were once valid but have passed their validity period; self-signed certificates were never signed by a trusted CA regardless of date
Expired certs fail date validation specifically; unable-to-verify fails CA chain validation and the certificate may still be within its validity period
